markdownRemark.html:
You might have noticed that we struggled a lot to define what is Acid House in our new show. And you are right, it's really hard to make sense of all these sub-genres. There are too many of them. Every few years a new wave of artists comes along sound tagged with a new genre label.

Are Skrillex, Diplo or David Guetta House? Nowadays, it is called EDM but the basic formula is for almost 40 years the same.

In the beginning, there was only one style. It started all in Chicago, some guys in a basement misused some drum-machines and synthesizers developed to accompany studio musicians, replayed some disco hits and boom we got House music. Soon after, they found a even more peculiar machine called TB-303 which could be used to create a sound resembling tweeting birds stuck in a toaster and suddenly we got acid House. My personal favorite is Adonis with 'No Way Back' which sounds like late night drive in the industrial zone with the devil on your mind you just sold your soul to.

To be complete the machine was already played on some other records before but its sound did not gain mainstream momentum. Already in 1979 an Indian film musician used the TB-303 extensively to fulfill his vision traditional Ragas on a disco beat.

Nonetheless, according to Wikipedia, the credits to go to Phuture and DJ Pierre as the inventors of the Acid sound. But as always, when a new music genre is born it's hard to point down to one specific person or group as originators. It was a collective effort which did not stop with just producing and publish records. It was a whole DIY way of dealing with music and life.

Later in the 80ies things got a bit complicated because House travelled to Detroit where some young DJs, notably the Belleville three shaped Techno under the influence of some early European electronic artists. In New York producers and DJs referred back to the colorful disco past of the city in form of garage House was discovered. I don't wanna recall the whole history of House (we can't be accurate) but DJs like Tony Humphries or labels such as Nu-groove, strictly-rhythm hosted some of the finest House records in the late 80ies full of soulful vocals and smooth chords but also some solid acid bombs. Bobby Konders combined added Dub

In the meantime American dance music was exported back to Europe influencing a whole generation of young musicians. Especially, in UK lot of local bands adopted the synthesiszers and drum machines into their setup creating a sound which does not follow any genre restriction. Bands such as Happy Mondays, Stone-Roses or New-Order had one foot in foot in the concert hall and another one in a sweaty club full of ravers high on extacy. But it was not until the summer of love in 1988 until acid House parties were called raves. Every weekend thousand of ravers went into clubs or outside raves celebrating hedonism as a response to their fad life perspectives in a country

In places like hacienda, bands and DJ shared the stage in equal parts playing guitars and records. Moreover due to a lack of regulation everywhere in the country illegal parties were organized. But it was not until the summer of love 1988 when these parties were called raves.
